intro: Papaver pavoninum var. freynii, commonly known as the Freyn's poppy, is a rare and striking botanical species native to specific regions of North America. It belongs to the Papaveraceae family and is characterized by its vibrant, often red or orange, cup-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid environments, showcasing adaptations to harsh conditions. Its leaves are palmately lobed, and the flowers bloom in late spring to early summer. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in some areas.
